abstract: Bankers and lawyers said banks competed to see who could hire the most politically connected recent college graduates.
snippet: Bankers and lawyers said banks competed to see who could hire the most politically connected recent college graduates.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Wall Street’s biggest banks have hired the sons and daughters of senior Chinese government officials in the hopes that they can open doors and secure deals in the world’s fastest-growing major economy.

headline.main: Many Wall St. Banks Woo Children of Chinese Leaders
headline.print_headline: Many Wall St. Banks Woo Children of Chinese Leaders

abstract: Wall Street banks have for years hired “princelings” in the hopes of securing deals in China. | An glitch at Goldman Sachs sent errant orders of stock options into the market. | The founder of Barnes & Noble has dropped a bid to buy the company’s bookstores. | William A. Ackman continues to bet the government will shut down Herbalife.
snippet: Wall Street banks have for years hired “princelings” in the hopes of securing deals in China. | An glitch at Goldman Sachs sent errant orders of stock options into the market. | The founder of Barnes & Noble has dropped a bid to buy the company’s ...
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s biggest banks have for years hired the children of senior Chinese government officials in the hopes that they can open doors and secure deals, David Barboza reports in The New York Times. The hirings, while not well publicized, were no secret. But they are gaining new attention after a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation has raised the question of whether such practices crossed a line at JPMorgan Chase.

abstract: An outside review of Bloomberg L.P.’s practices found that a controversial report that compared the damage in an Italian town after a bad deal with JPMorgan to the fallout from the Nazis’ occupation in World War II went “too far.”
snippet: An outside review of Bloomberg L.P.’s practices found that a controversial report that compared the damage in an Italian town after a bad deal with JPMorgan to the fallout from the Nazis’ occupation in World War II went “too far.”
lead_paragraph: An outside review of Bloomberg L.P.’s practices found that a controversial article that compared the damage in an Italian town after a bad deal with JPMorgan Chase to the fallout from the Nazis’ occupation in World War II went “too far.”

headline.main: JPMorgan Chase Not Akin to Nazis, Report Finds
